Nope. We all spoke here among us who know something about firearms, and curiously they listened to us instead of the basically uninformed "anti-gun" crowd. Not a terrible surprise there, even relatively fanatical politicians can come to the right decision when faced with facts that don't support the efficacy of their proposed legislation. Of course you couldn't explain ANYTHING to Nancy Pelosi, so she'll go right on pushing gun laws no one wants, but for most the idea that somehow criminals won't tend to obey gun laws seems to pretty much make the case that this is a problem that can't be solved by legislation but rather education. You want people to not treat deadly weapons like toys, then you want to start education early, intensively, and at all grade levels in a method appropriate to that level. Basic safety only until Junior High follow by NRA Junior rifle (.22 caliber rim-fires at 50 feet, single shot only) and progressing to more advanced competitions later as electives. Teach people what firearms can do, teach them to shoot, and you'll have considerably less issue with impulsive use of firearms, less stupid accidents, fewer suicides, but more people that someone deliberately wanted dead, and probably more from a distance where "getting the license plate number" isn't going to be happening.

why not whine about the billions spend for coronary heart disease, a disease of lifestyle (99% of them due to being fat and or smoking).. if you are fat and smoke and eat too much red meat you are going to clog your arteries and need bypasses like D. Cheney....paid for by all the people who eat right and live right.... so the fact is that since smoking costs more than hiv why aren't you demanding smoking be outlawed or that by passes be not covered by insurance and let each dumbo who needs one pay the full couple hundred K bill???? (they are not a cure, anyway.... there is a cure.... a vegan diet, no smoking and exercise.....that costs nothing)...
rodent, I had hope for you, but you are beyond redemption. You are now on my ignore list.

Message.Title: Jeff Hanneman dies at 49
Message.Msg: RIP..

You missed the point of the post... but that's OK, wouldn't be the first time. Lucky my man, I think smokers are paying a pretty heavy price both in cost of the taxes levied on the product and with their lives. I have no problem with folks that misbehave paying more. The Problem is that the ones that mostly need to pay more won't. If your are poor and on Obamacare you will being paying zero in premiums...soo, what leverage do you have for these folks to stop their bad habits? At lest your are consistent, you even attack me when I in principal agree with you on the morning after pill.

bidder, "In a significant reversal just one month after two Catholic hospitals refused to treat a victim of sexual assault, Germany's bishops on Thursday approved the use of the "morning-after pill" in rape cases. German commentators say the step doesn't go far enough." Now a days, rape victims and victims of incest maybe as young as 12 or 13 years old. Many of these children are well build and may get pregnant. Don't you think that victims of any age should be able to get the morning after pill?

Careful there cowboy there be a diff between "Democrats" and "Liberals". They aren't quite the same thing, although there is strong correlation. Neither are all Republicans "Conservatives" although its a pretty fair assumption in most cases. And you got the phrase wrong, it goes, "15 year olds who want morning after pills are adults, 25 year olds who won't buy insurance are children." Please not that most young adults don't buy insurance because it goes against their personal interest to buy insurance when they're at low probability of needing it and a social safety net already exists that would catch them if they got unlucky at a very time when they need every cent to get started, in other words, making a perfectly rational choice based on the economic conditions at hand. Remove the safety net and the equation changes, but Obama et al don't want to change the equation. they just want to make everyone ignore it.

Very well build and may get pregnant? Dude, it doesn't have anything to do with build and have everything to do with menarche. Fortunately for you not everyone arguing your positions is as poorly informed. Meanwhile, if you want to advance the cause of freedom of choice, keep your mouth closed about reproductive biology. We'll just say you're background in that area is to the ignorant side of light.

smokers come no where near covering the several hundred K $$ costs of the the ER and the bypass surgeries for their lifestyle choice.....and fyi..... it has already been covered by Reagancare, known as "bushcare" at the ER.... as I have told you countless times..... Reagan and the gop senate did The Emergency Medical Treatment and Active Labor Act (EMTALA ...It requires hospitals to provide care to anyone needing emergency healthcare treatment regardless of citizenship, legal status or ability to pay..... I know a libertartian who refused to have medical insurance but everyone else paid for his $500 K ER and quad bypass.... thanks to Bushcare..... and btw.... he paid no taxes for tobacco since he grew his own... and even if he had it would be nowhere near the cost of his medical treatment.

Yeah there's nothing like a good wack in the face with the flounder of logic to make you want to hold your nose and swear off flounder. Same with a good smack of (mostly) the truth. Pity you're putting Rodent on ignore, he's more obnoxious than you are, but he's also right more often. You might learn a couple things. One, how to NOT be obnoxious so you get your points across better (areas where liberal social principles have been most strongly promulgated and enforced are the most socially blighted urban areas in the nation), without totally #$%$ someone off (especially in the colored communities doesn't go over well despite the relative truth value).

Message.Title: EPA is not the enemy
Message.Msg: "Source: Office of Management and Budget But no where was the effect greater than with EPA regulations themselves. Over the last decade, they imposed as much as $45 billion in costs on the economy, but they also drove as much as $640 billion in benefits: The OMB found that a decade’s worth of major federal rules had produced annual benefits to the U.S. economy of between $193 billion and $800 billion and impose aggregate costs of $57 billion to $84 billion. “These ranges are reported in 2001 dollars and reflect the uncertain benefits and costs of each rule,” the report noted. Rules from the EPA added significantly to both sides of the ledger. “It should be clear that the rules with the highest benefits and the highest costs, by far, come from the Environmental Protection Agency and in particular its Office of Air and Radiation,” the OMB study said. EPA regulations accounted for between 58% and 80% of the benefits the study found as well as 44% to 54% of the costs. Air regulations accounted for nearly 99% of EPA rule benefits, according to the report."

I am giving up trying to have a rational conversation with you, but I have one last suggestion...we need to tax bathhouses to cover the cost of AIDS treatments. You would agree, if we were to apply your logic.

Hmm, are genetal warts, herpes, Syphilis , gonorrhea covered? How about mono(mononucleosis) Lung disease when shown smoking caused it? Ahh but that is right, you get to decide what behaviour is correct, and you want the govt to get involved in peoples choices when you want them to.

yep, that's it, but remember, you where the one whining about how health insurance has been done all along.... and btw, ususally your type whine about sin taxes and the "nanny" state...too.. I guess you have changed your tune.

Message.Title: Arms race
Message.Msg: 5-Year-Old Boy Killed Sister With Gun Made For Kids By Annie-Rose Strasser on May 2, 2013 at 11:00 am On Tuesday, a five-year-old Kentucky boy accidentally shot and killed his two-year-old sister with a gun he’d been given as a birthday present. The weapon, a small rifle, was manufactured specifically for children’s use. The boy’s weapon was a “My First Rifle” .22-caliber gun from Keystone Sporting Arms’ youth branch, Crickett’s website markets itself “especially for youth shooters.” The firearms come in several neon colors, and the website even has a “kids corner” featuring pictures of small children with guns: Crickett does not manufacture bullets. The company offers books for “Grades 2-3 and up,” and says their guns are “ideally sized for children four to ten years old.” The militarization of children has been tragically spotlighted in the aftermath of the horrific shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary in Newtown, Connecticut last December. Since then, the country has paid heart-sickening attention to the myriad accidental shootings that have taken place around the country, and the growth of a market of bulletproof children’s clothing. In one week alone last month, four people were shot by toddlers. "
SEC, you just blasted them with naked truth.
So bidder is all for raising taxes ? He needs to stop drinking.
fugbar, Have looked at yourself lately?
